items.title: Music Tangled To Memories
items.summary: Yesterday I was studying as usual, listening to random music that Spotify thought I may like when… The light in us all started playing. It honestly left me standing there, with just a thought (a very silly thought at that).
items.content_html:
Yesterday I was studying as usual, listening to random music that Spotify thought I may like when… The light in us all started playing. It honestly left me standing there, with just a thought (a very silly thought at that). Me playing Minecraft following ArticKraft’s videos on base building. Silly, I warned ya, nevertheless it left me thinking because I haven’t even glanced at that YouTuber since I was 12 or 13, and the fact that when the song played I immediately remembered the name of the YouTuber is wild. The same happens with, for example, the opening music from an Apple Event, I can recall precisely what event it was played and what they introduced at it.

This is an example of how music is really tangled into memories, I like to think of it as if it were the EXIF data (aka. Metadata) of a picture, except that with no aperture, camera and manufacturer’s data, but with the smells, music and good memories that can be retained from that moment. Again, this is wild. There is a chapter in the book called Springer Handbook of Systematic Musicology called Long-Term Memory for Music and it explains exceptionally well what I’m trying to convey over here… I might just be a Senior HS Student, therefore, just a mere opinion that has no weigh on anything, but I just like thinking about this stuff. Anyways, thanks for reading my silly thoughts, catch ya in the next one!

items.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
items.summary: Well... I finally gave into the Apple ecosystem after trying countless (as a matter of fact, 5) android tablets, none of which, were up for my school note-taking life. Nevertheless, when Apple announced in their Apple Event the 9th…
items.content_html:
Well... I finally gave into the Apple ecosystem after trying countless (as a matter of fact, 5) android tablets, none of which, were up for my school note-taking life. Nevertheless, when Apple announced in their Apple Event the 9th Generation of the iPad I thought to myself, "Why not?" And got it with a Logitech Crayon because... Honestly, I know that it has way less functionality than the Apple Pencil, but the shape... ANYWAYS! We're getting off track. Where were we... Oh yeah! The iPad.

From the moment I booted iPadOS 15 I fell in love with the simple yet incredibly powerful OS (And to be completely honest, I was blown away by the multitasking). To be clear, my goal buying the iPad was to have a device that I could take to school, get rid of my physical notebooks and books, and just... Carry it! Practically no weight at all.

As of writing this post, I've been using the iPad for a month and a bit. I've been using GoodNotes for my notetaking, as well as Quick Notes for when I have to jot something on the go (Perfect for when the teacher starts saying what's gonna be in the exam and you have nothing open). You might be wondering what has been of my previous notes on the physical notebooks, so the answer is... I scanned them all! it might not conserve the OCR but to be honest, I didn't have that either before.

On another note, shortcuts has been of great help! As you can see by the screenshot above, I have a very handy dandy Shortcut to add a new exam to my calendar following my usual naming scheme, perfection! (Also starring... Widgetsmith and Apollo!)

So yeah, in conclusion... This iPad is really (from what I've been able to tell for now) a great device!

items.title: The Orange
items.summary: The other day in English class, we read a poem. A really interesting poem at that. It is called The Orange (Look! Just loke this entry's title! How surprising), and this poem is... well, it makes you think about…
items.content_html:
The other day in English class, we read a poem. A really interesting poem at that.
It is called The Orange (Look! Just loke this entry's title! How surprising), and this poem is... well, it makes you think about how even the smallest things in life can make you happy. It makes me feel like we shouldn’t take everything seriously and we should just enjoy life, take a walk, breathe... Just getting away from the busy life that is ours. 

This poem was written (or at least published) in 1993, so it's as we say now.. Pre-COVID. Life as it is, and reading this made me realize that we used to life a quieter and more relaxed life than we do as of right now. Anyways, here's the poem, by Wendy Cope:

items.summary: Hello, and welcome to my blog! As what may have brought you here, I do not know, but I sincerely hope that you stay to follow on my... how to say it... my silly little adventures trying to figure…
items.content_html:
Hello, and welcome to my blog! As what may have brought you here, I do not know, but I sincerely hope that you stay to follow on my... how to say it... my silly little adventures trying to figure out everything to be honest (maybe I'll even honor this page's name and I'll do weekly releases!). Anyways... If you'd like to get notifications whenever I post anything here, I have a Telegram channel (<--- click there :D) for you! 

Thanks for checking this out! Cya in the next issue!
- Intron014.
